issues.text: What is the scope of s. 83(3)? Is it open to the Tribunal acting under this provision to direct new instances of the corrupt practices to be added to the list? And if it is, is that what it did in the present case?

anchor.surface_text: Now, we start with this that s. 83 3 grants a power to the Tribunal to amend particulars in a list. What is its scope? Is it open to the Tribunal acting under this provision to direct new instances of the corrupt practices to be added to the list? And if it is, is that what it did in the present case? It is conten

issues.text: Whether O. VI, r. 17 of the Civil Procedure Code applies to proceedings before the Election Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: That raises the question which has been very much debated both in the Election Tribunals and in the High Courts of the States as to whether 0. VI, r. 17 applies to proceedings before Election Tribunals. Mr. K. S. Krish- naswami Ayyangar, learned counsel for the respondent, contends that it does, by force of s. 90 2 of the Act

issues.text: What is the meaning of the word 'trial' in s. 90(2)?

anchor.surface_text: Taking the first contention, the point for decision is as to what the word trial in s. 90 2 means. According to the appellants, it must be understood in a limited sense, as meaning the final hearing of the petition, consisting of examination of witnesses, filing documents and addressing arguments.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal has power under O. VI r. 17 to allow amendment introducing new grounds or charges after the limitation period under s. 81.

anchor.surface_text: It is next contended for the appellants that even if s.83 3 does not exclude the application of 0. VI, r. 17 to the proceedings before the Tribunal, the exercise of the power under that rule must, nevertheless, be subject to the conditions prescribed by s. 81 for presentation of an election petition

issues.text: Whether the allegations in para 7(c) of the original petition raised a charge of corrupt practice under s. 123(8).

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to read into the allegations in para 7 c as originally framed any clear and categorical statement of a charge under s. 123 8 , or indeed under any of the provisions of the Election law. The respondent does not dispute that the language in which the allegation in para 7 c is couched does

issues.text: Whether the first appellant contravened s. 123(7) of the Act by employing Ganga Prasad and Viswanath Pande for payment in connection with the election.

arguments.claim: s.83(3) does not authorize inclusion of new instances of corrupt practices, only fuller particulars of existing instances

anchor.surface_text: It is contended by the learned Solicitor-General on behalf of the appellants that s. 83 3  does not authorize the inclusion of new instances of corrupt practices, and that all that could be ordered under that provision was giving of fuller particulars in respect of instances given in the petition.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: behalf of the appellants is that if the provisions of the Civil Procedure Code are held to be applicable in their entirety to the trial of election pe

arguments.court_reasoning: s.81(1) grounds are categories in s.100 etc., s.83(1) material facts general, s.83(2) particulars include instances; power extends to new instances relating to charge

arguments.claim: Distinction between grounds (s.81), facts (s.83(1)), particulars (s.83(2)); new instances not allowed under s.83(3)

anchor.surface_text: Section 81 requires that the election petition should state the grounds on which it is founded. Section 83 1  enacts that it should contain -a concise statement of the material facts on which the petitioner relies, and s. 83 2  provides that the petition should be accompanied by a list containing full particulars

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r s. 92 that the Tribunal was to have the powers of companyrts under the Code of Civil Procedure in respect of the matters mentioned therein, as those

arguments.court_reasoning: Legislature distinguishes grounds as categories/objections, facts as general statements, particulars as instances of corrupt practices

arguments.claim: Tribunal has power under s.83(3) to allow new instances if they relate to a charge contained in the petition

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with this contention. In our opinion, s. 81 1  and s. 83, sub-ss.  1  and  2 , when correctly understood, support the contention of the respondent that the Tribunal has authority to allow an amendment even when that involves inclusion of new instances, provided they relate to a charge

arguments.claim: English precedents support allowing particulars including new instances (Beal v. Smith, Greenoch)

anchor.surface_text: We are fortified in this conclusion by decisions of English Courts, on statutory provisions which are in pari materia with our enactment. Section 20 of the Parliamentary Elections Act, 1868... Beal v. Smith...

arguments.claim: Word 'matter' in s.83(3) wider than 'particulars', includes grounds; allows fresh instances

anchor.surface_text: The assumption underlying this contention is that the word matter in s. 83  3  means the same thing as particulars. We see no reason why we should put this narrow construction on the word matter.

arguments.claim: O. VI r.17 CPC does not apply to Tribunal proceedings because trial means only final hearing

anchor.surface_text: But it is contended for the appellants that O. VI, r. 17 cannot be held to apply to proceedings before the Tribunal by reason of s. 90  2 , because  1  under that section, it is only the trial of the election petition that has to be in accordance with the provisions of the Civil Procedure Code,

arguments.court_reasoning: 'Trial' in s.90(2) means entire proceedings from transfer under s.86 to award; supported by ss.86(4),88,90(4),92

arguments.claim: s.92 lists specific powers excluding amendment under O.VI r.17

anchor.surface_text: and as amendment of pleadings is not one of them, O. VI, r. 17 must be held to have been excluded from its jurisdiction

arguments.court_reasoning: s.92 powers without Act limitation, irreducible minimum; s.90(2) subject to Act but covers procedure including amendment

arguments.claim: Distinction between procedure (s.90(2)) and powers (s.92); amendment is power not procedure

anchor.surface_text: the Act makes a distinction between procedure and powers, s. 90  2  extends the provisions of the Civil Procedure Code to proceedings before Tribunals only in respect of procedure, and power to order amendment under 0. VI, r. 17 is not

arguments.court_reasoning: No antithesis; application for amendment is procedural step under s.90(2)

arguments.claim: s.83(3) special provision excludes general O.VI r.17 (expressio unius exclusio alterius)

anchor.surface_text: s. 90 2  is, in any event, subject to the provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder, and the power of amendment under s. 83  3  being limited to particulars, the general power of amendment under 0. VI, r. 17 must be held to have been excluded.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.83(3) only for particulars; other amendments under O.VI r.17; maxim inapplicable as s.83(3) not comprehensive

arguments.claim: O.VI r.17 applies via s.90(2) as trial includes entire proceedings

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the provisions of Chapter III read as a whole, clearly show that trial is used as meaning the entire proceedings before the Tribunal from the time when the petition is transferred to it under s. 86 until the pronouncement of the award.

arguments.claim: Even if O.VI r.17 applies, cannot allow new grounds/charges after limitation under s.81
arguments.court_reasoning: s.90(2) subject to Act; no power to extend limitation; new grounds after bar invalid (Maude v Lowley)

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to read into the allegations in para 7 c as originally framed any clear and categorical statement of a charge under s. 123 8 , or indeed under any of the provisions of the Election law. The respondent does not dispute that the language

arguments.court_reasoning: Charges quasi-criminal, must be clear/precise; para 7(c) worthless

arguments.claim: Charges of corrupt practices quasi-criminal, require clear precise allegations

anchor.surface_text: It should not be forgotten that charges of corrupt practices are quasi-criminal in character, and that the allegations relating thereto must be sufficiently clear and precise to bring home the charges to the candidates

anchor.surface_text: In this view, there is no scope for the application of the maxim, expressio unius exclusio alterius, on which the appellants rely.

arguments.court_reasoning: No evidence of 'employment'; contract for services (piece-work), not control test met

holdings.text: s. 83(3) grants power to Tribunal to allow amendment of particulars including new instances of corrupt practices provided they relate to a charge/ground contained in the petition.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with this contention. In our opinion, s. 81 1  and s. 83, sub-ss.  1  and  2 , when correctly understood, support the contention of the respondent that the Tribunal has authority to allow an amendment even when that involves inclusion of new instances, provided they relate to a charge

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading of ss.81(1),83(1),(2): grounds are categories in s.100 etc., facts general, particulars include instances; English precedents analogous.

holdings.text: O. VI r.17 CPC applies to proceedings before Election Tribunal by virtue of s.90(2) RPA.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the provisions of Chapter III read as a whole, clearly show that trial is used as meaning the entire proceedings before the Tribunal from the time when the petition is transferred to it under s. 86 until the pronouncement of the award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.90(2) applies CPC procedure to 'trial' encompassing entire proceedings; s.92 specifies minimum powers without excluding others; precedents like Jagan Nath support.

holdings.text: The word 'trial' in s.90(2) means the entire proceedings before the Tribunal from transfer under s.86 to pronouncement of award.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the provisions of Chapter III read as a whole, clearly show that trial is used as meaning the entire proceedings before the Tribunal from the time when the petition is transferred to it under s. 86 until the pronouncement of the award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Context of Chapter III (ss.86(4),88,90(4),92); trial includes pre-hearing steps like issues, amendments.

holdings.text: Tribunal has no power under O.VI r.17 or otherwise to allow amendment introducing new grounds/charges of corrupt practice after expiry of limitation period under s.81.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.90(2) subject to Act provisions; cannot extend limitation; English precedents (Maude v Lowley) binding.

holdings.text: Allegations in para 7(c) of original petition do not raise any charge of corrupt practice under s.123(8) or any provision of Election law; amendment introduces new charge.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to read into the allegations in para 7 c as originally framed any clear and categorical statement of a charge under s. 123 8 , or indeed under any of the provisions of the Election law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Vague language ('could' not 'did'); quasi-criminal charges require precise pleadings; alters petition character substantially.

holdings.text: First appellant did not contravene s.123(7) by employing Ganga Prasad and Viswanath Pande for payment; they were engaged on contract for services (piece-work), not contract of service/employment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of employment/control test; distinction contract for services vs of service; applies precedents like Dharangadhara.

holdings.text: Order of amendment dated Nov 28, 1953 allowing new allegations in para 7(c) is beyond Tribunal's power and set aside; finding of s.123(8) violation reversed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment introduces new barred charge; no discretion to allow after delay without explanation.

anchor.surface_text: Beal v. Smith  1 . There, the election petition merely stated that the respondent by himself and other. person. on his behalf, was guilty if bribery, treating and undue influence. The respondent took out an application for an order that the petition be taken off the file on the ground that it merely stated the grounds but number the facts companst

precedents.cited_proposition: election petition sufficiently states grounds and facts if charge is set out, particulars of corrupt practices can be ordered later to ensure fair trial
precedents.cited_holding: order for particulars three days prior to trial proper; generality of petition not fatal

anchor.surface_text: A similar decision was given in the Greenoch Election Case, a report of which is given in a footnote at page 150 of Beal v. Smith  1  1869  L. R. 4 C- P.145.

precedents.cited_proposition: similar to Beal v Smith on sufficiency of petition form and ordering particulars

anchor.surface_text: Thus,in the Carrickfergus Case  1 , in ordering  1  1869 1 OM. H. 264, 265. an application for amending particulars, so as to include matters which had only then come to the knowledge of the petitioner, OBrien, J., observed In some respects the Petitioner came down here manifestly ignorant of the exact grounds upon which several of the charges of the Petition were founded.

precedents.cited_proposition: allow amendment of particulars to add facts recently come to knowledge in election petitions to ensure searching enquiry into purity of election
precedents.cited_holding: reasonable to allow amendment of bill of particulars upon proper case

anchor.surface_text: In the Dublin Case  1 , the order was one directing a list. of particulars to be amended, the Court observing I shall allow the utmost latitude to amend, unless it is a case in which I see that the party kept back information at the time the list was furnished.

precedents.cited_proposition: allow utmost latitude to amend list of particulars unless information kept back
precedents.cited_holding: order directing amendment of list of particulars

anchor.surface_text: Now, in A. G. v. Sillem  1  it was stated by Lord Westbury that the word practiceand it means, as observed in Poyser V. Mixors  2  the same - thing as procedure- denotes the rules that make or guide the Curcus cirise, and regulate the proceedings ina cause within the walls or limits of the Court itself .

precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of 'practice' as rules guiding proceedings in court including steps in prosecution or defence
precedents.cited_holding: 'practice' denotes rules regulating proceedings within court limits

anchor.surface_text: the word practiceand it means, as observed in Poyser V. Mixors  2  the same - thing as procedure- denotes the rules that make or guide the Curcus cirise, and regulate the proceedings ina cause within the walls or limits of the Court itself . And these proceedings include all ,steps, which might be taken in the prosecution or defence thereof, including an application for amendment.

In Maude v. Lowley  3 , the point arose for decision whether the power conferred on the Election Court by s. 21 5  of the Corrupt Practices  Municipal Elections  Act, 1872, to try the petition, subject to the provisions of the Act, as if it were a cause within its jurisdiction, carried with it a power to order amendment of the petition.

precedents.cited_proposition: election court has power to order amendment of petition when trying as a cause
precedents.cited_holding: power to try as cause carries power to amend petition

anchor.surface_text: and as observed in Sitaram v. Yoqrajising  1 , they are A.I.R. 1953 BOM. 293. the irreducible minimum which the Tribunal is to possess.

precedents.cited_proposition: powers under s.92 are irreducible minimum for Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: Turning next to the authorities, the decision of this Court in Jagan Nath v. Jaswant Singh  1  goes far to conclude the question in favour of the respondent. In that case, a petition to set aside an election was filed without impleading one of the candidates, Baijnath,  1 1954 S.C.R. 892, who had been nominated but had withdrawn -from the contest.

precedents.cited_proposition: Tribunal has power under O.1 rr.9,10,13 to implead parties; trial includes pre-hearing stages
precedents.cited_holding: non-joinder not fatal; power to direct impleadment

anchor.surface_text: In Sitaram v. Yograjsingh  1  it was held that Procedure in s. 90 2 and I powers in s. 92 were interchangeable terms, that the procedure applicable under s. 90 2  was wider than what would be applicable to the hearing of a. suit, and that the Tribunal had power in a proper case to order amendment of a petition.

precedents.cited_proposition: procedure and powers interchangeable; Tribunal can amend petition under s.90(2)
precedents.cited_holding: power to order amendment of petition

precedents.citation: Sheo Mahadeo Prasad v. Deva Sharan 2

anchor.surface_text: In Sheo Mahadeo Prasad v. Deva Sharan 2 , it was held that the application of 0. VI, r. 17 to proceedings before the Tribunal was excluded by section 83 3  of the Act.

precedents.case_name: Sheo Mahadeo Prasad v Deva Sharan
precedents.cited_holding: O.VI r.17 does not apply to election tribunal

anchor.surface_text: The decisions in Maude v. Lowley 1  and Birkbeck and others v. Bullard  1  are relied on in support of this contention.

precedents.cited_proposition: amendment raising new charge not allowed if fresh petition barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: The decisions in Maude v. Lowley 1  and Birkbeck and others v. Bullard  1  are relied on in support of this contention. In Maude v. Lowley  1 , the facts were that an election petition was filed alleging that the successful candidate had employed as paid canvassers residents of the ward, and that the election was, in consequence, void.

precedents.cited_proposition: no amendment adding new charge after limitation period for petition
precedents.cited_holding: amendment power subject to Act's limitation provisions

anchor.surface_text: This was followed in Clark v. Wallond  3 .

precedents.cited_proposition: followed Maude v Lowley on no amendment for time-barred new charges

anchor.surface_text: as laid down in Charan Das v. Amir Khan  1 . But this is to ignore the restriction imposed by s. 90 2  that the procedure of the Court under the Code of Civil Procedure in which 0. VI, r. 17 is comprised, is to apply subject to the provisions of the Act, and the rules,  1 1920 L.R. 47 I.A. 255.

precedents.cited_proposition: bar of limitation relevant to discretion on amendment but does not affect jurisdiction
precedents.cited_holding: in exceptional cases amendment allowed even if suit barred

anchor.surface_text: Vide the observations of Lord Simonds L.C. in Senanayake v. Navaratne  1 . In the present case, having regard to the circumstances stated above, the order of amendment would be open to grave criticism even if it had been made in an ordinary litigation, and in an election matter, it is indefensible.

precedents.cited_proposition: election disputes to be determined with despatch; special jurisdiction for that

anchor.surface_text: There is in law a well- established distinction between a contract for services, and a contract of service, and it was thus stated in Collins v. Hertfordshire Central Council  1  In the one case the master can order or require what is to be done while in the other case he can number only order or require what is to be done but how it shall be done.

precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between contract for services (independent contractor) and contract of service (employee): control over how work done
precedents.cited_holding: master orders what, not how in contract for services

precedents.citation: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra  2

anchor.surface_text: This Court had occasion to go into this question somewhat fully in Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra  2  , and it was there held that the real test for deciding whether the contract was one of employment was to find out whether the agreement was for the personal labour of the person engaged, and that if that was so, the contract was one of employment, whether the work was time- work or piece-work or whether the employee did the whole of the work himself or whether he obtained the assistance of other persons also for the work.

precedents.case_name: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd v State of Saurashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: test for contract of employment: whether for personal labour; applies to piece-work or time-work
precedents.cited_holding: personal labour test determines employment even if assistance obtained
